text:
(1)
Hancock Street, west side, north from Houston to Bleecker
Streets, the entire length of Hancock Street.
1926.

(2)
The same, two years later, showing Hancock Street in the process of being absorbed by Sixth Avenue Extension. The entire west side of Hancock Street, and part of the east side, has been demolished. The municipal subway has been cut through and boarded over.
September 1, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Hancock Street, west side, north from Houston to Bleecker
Streets, the entire length of Hancock Street.
1926.

(2)
The same, two years later, showing Hancock Street in the process of being absorbed by Sixth Avenue Extension. The entire west side of Hancock Street, and part of the east side, has been demolished. The municipal subway has been cut through and boarded over.
September 1, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

168 West Houston Street (33 Hancock Street); and Nos. 164, 162-160, 158, north side, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of Hancock Street, (the future N.E. corner of Sixth Avenue and Houston Street), seen from the northern end of Congress Street across the little plaza formed by the concurrence of Houston Street, Bedford Street, and the western section of Houston Street (formerly Hammersley Street). Every single building visible in this picture is to be demolished the following year, when work begins on the new Independent (Municipal) Subway and the extension of Sixth Avenue south from its original beginning at Carmine Street and Minetta Lane. The Houston Street branch of the new subway will curve under the north side of Houston Street, where the tenement houses and moving picture theatre appear in this picture.

1926.

Sixth Avenue Extension South, (under construction) north from W. Houston to Bleecker Streets (intersection in the center) showing both a new thoroughfare and a Municipal subway (Eighth Avenue) under construction. Buildings on the right formerly formed the easterly side of Hancock Street. Note the San Carlos Mission still standing. This will shortly follow as the new Sixth Avenue will run in a direct line from foreground and this is in the center of same.

May 12, 1927.
Views 1 and 2

P. L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue Extension South - Houston Street (West) - Bleeker Street.

title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue Extension South - Houston Street (West) - Bleeker Street.

text:
Congress Street, south from West Houston to King Streets.
About 1927.

(1)
Bedford Street, northwest from Houston Street at Congress (Sixth Avenue Extension). Bedford Street runs northwest, parallel to the third section (originally Herring's Street) of Bleecker Street, to Christopher Street, and, like the corresponding section of Bleecker, lies almost entirely within the old Herring farm. The farm line crosses Bedford Street at Nos. 10 and 17 (about where two cars are parked together on the east side of the street a hundred feet north of the plaza).
The little plaza in the foreground is formed by the junction of the original Houston Street (from the Bowery to this point), the former Hammersley Street (at the left), which in 1858 was made part of Houston Street, and Bedford Street, which on the angle of Bleecker Street, might have been absorbed by Houston had it not been for Hammersley Street. At the right, Hancock Extension, comes into the plaza at right angles to Houston Street. At the left of View No. 2, may be seen the billboards at the right angle junction of Congress (originally Smith) Street and Houston Street.
October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Another view, with the cameras more to the west.
October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, from the ground, from and including Sixth Avenue, three and a half years later.
February 20, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

Congress Street, south from but not including Houston Street. Also shown, is the new Sixth Avenue Extension (of which this will be a part) southward. The house with the pitched roof is No. 15 King Street and is at the N. W. corner of these two streets.

October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

Sixth Avenue Extension South, north from West Houston Street. Shown under construction is the new thoroughfare and the subway under same. This incorporated the former Hancock Street. The 6 story tenements at the left are at the bend formed by Cornelia Street. This appears in both Views 1 and 2. View 3 is taken from atop the Graphic Arts Building on Varick Street.
Note the dome atop the new church of the St. Carlos Missionary Fathers. This organization was formerly located where the circular open pit is in the center of View 2.
The Sixth Avenue "El" line turns eastward on W. 3rd Street. This structure was taken down in 1938.

View 1: September 1, 1928
View 2: October 11, 1928
View 3: Juhe 23, 1930

P. L. Sperr

Reader s... caption is mistaken. Should read: "The six-story tenements at the left are at the bend of BEDFORD street."

title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Houston Street (West).

text:
West Houston Street (running from center foreground to right background), east from Hancock Street, and showing a general view of the surrounding area in a northeasterly direction. Shown under construction is the subway curve of the Independent (Eighth Ave.) System at the N.E. corner of Hancock Street. The white building, in the center, is Mills House No. 1 and is on the south side of Bleecker Street, from Sullivan to Thompson Streets.

June 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

West Houston Street, north side, (in foreground not shown) between Sixth Ave. Extension (left) and MacDougal (right) Streets, showing, under construction, a portion of the Eighth Ave. Subway, making a sharp bend from West Houston Street, and proceeding northward, under the new Sixth Ave. Extension. Also shown (left) are the rears of 6-story houses, Nos. 13 to 1 Hancock Street. (now 260 to 270 Sixth Ave). On the right appears a view northward on the east side of MacDougal Street.

June 15, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) 196 West Houston Street, north side, west of Sixth Avenue and Bedford Street.
June 15, 1930. P.L. Sperr.

(2) The same, and showing a further view westward to No. 206.
May 29, 1935. P.L. Sperr.

(1) 196 West Houston Street, north side, west of Sixth Avenue and Bedford Street.
June 15, 1930. P.L. Sperr.

(2) The same, and showing a further view westward to No. 206.
May 29, 1935. P.L. Sperr.

title: 6th Avenue at Bedford Street and Bleecker Street, East side to , Manhattan

text:
195 West Houston Street (originally 30 Hammersley Street), south side, west of Sixth Avenue (former Congress Street). The brick facing on this frame house may have been as recent as 1922. 1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(1) Sixth Ave., (Extension), east side, south from West Houston, to and including King Streets. The two 5-story buildings whose rears are shown, are Nos. 5 and 3 King Street, at, and adjoining the N.E. corner of Sixth Ave. The 5-story house at the extreme right, is No. 4 King Street, and adjoins the S.E. corner of Sixth Ave., there being an empty lot at the corner (not seen).
May 29, 1935. P.L. Sperr.

(2) The same location several years later. West Houston Street is at the left.
April 5, 1939. P.L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Houston Street (West)- King Street.

original_title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Bedford Street to Downing Street.
text:
(1)
Sixth Ave., west side, north from Bedford (left) to Downing (right and across clearance) Streets as viewed from West Houston Street and showing a triangular block, bounded by these streets, under clearance. Across same appears structures on the north side of Downing Street. Downing Place, a concealed court formerly was located where the sign board stands and was opened to view by the construction of Sixth Ave. Extension.

P. L. Sperr.

December 11, 1937.

(2)
A view from in the clearance and in a southwestward direction showing the rear of buildings that face on Bedford Street; the 3-story rear structure being at the rear of No. 10. The south side of this building formed the southern boundary of the old Herring Farm (grounds would be on the right); the West Bayard Farm being opposite (left of same).

P. L. Sperr.

December 11, 1937.
